ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to analyze electrical circuits.

This course was definitely a step up from 200 or 201, but it did also have a sense of being a more foundational class. There was a quick review of past material the first two classes and then it was full steam ahead with transfer functions, second order circuits, Laplace transforms, and Fourier series. It made me realize how important it was to truly understand basic circuit analysis.
First and second order circuit analysis, bode plots, filters, transfer functions, Laplace transform and applications, Fourier series, Fourier transforms
More circuit application.
More on circuits, Laplace transform, Fourier transform, some simple active circuit layouts (in lab)
I have learnt techniques for analyzing complex circuits (Laplace and Fourier transforms)
advanced circuits
This class teaches second order circuits and many circuit analysis techniques.
Learned to analyze circuits and perform Laplace/Fourier transforms

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The lectures in this course were very straightforward (course structure followed the textbook) and Professor Tang would walk-through plenty of examples. The exams, though proctored and timed, were usually fair. 

Lab materials were shipped to us, which was very thoughtful. However, the first few labs were very hard to complete. I believe this was mostly a hardware problem since we were using some finnicky lab materials, but it did create a semester-long trend of the labs taking 2x longer because the kit wasn't cooperating.

Strengths: Following the book closely was very helpful since I could reinforce things I didn't understand in class by reading the textbook. I also thought that a lot of the lab projects were very interesting, and especially with the later ones, I felt really excited about what I had built.
Weaknesses: The lectures are very dry, and I feel like it could have been more interactive without cold calling on people.  There were also no scheduled office hours, and although the TFs were responsive and willing to meet, I think having regularly scheduled office hours is important for a STEM class.

Strength - the lectures were well organized and systematic, with weekly psets. 

Weakness - unfortunately the labs are still hard, and debugging *hardware* via Zoom is frightening... could get quite stressful doing the lab within the three hours.
Good course, great professor
fine

I thought the pace of the course was pretty good. I think it would be great if the course had peer tutors like the other EE classes. There were some moments in the course when the material was a little daunting and it would have been nice to have a little more support when doing those sections.

Lectures and exams were very fair. The textbook problems get a bit ridiculous bc questions aren't too well written sometimes, and lab through Zoom was pretty hard because the equipment quality was poor and it was hard for TAs to help. Otherwise a nice and well taught course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Independent lab-kits were a double-edged sword. On one hand, I had all the time in the world to figure out the lab manual and really work through the assignment and questions, but it was extremely difficult for the TA's to help us troubleshoot a failing circuit or weird graph results. We would only be able to share our circuits with the Zoom camera and this severely limited the TA's ability to help.

I liked having the live lecture as well as having it recorded because I could rewatch anything I needed to clarify.  I also thought that the labs worked fairly well despite the virtual format. Because of the pandemic, this is the first EE course I've had where the labs involved hands on components, and I think the labs really strengthened my circuit building skills.  One change I would make is to split the labs up instead of being 3 hours long because I always felt extremely drained and exhausted after sitting at my desk on Zoom for 3 hours.

The idea of mailing the comprehensive kit out was great, and really beneficial to preserving the meat of a full engineering course despite the challenges of remote learning. 

The only minor regret is I did not get to solder parts to the circuit board. I admit this is an entirely reasonable change to the lab, due to safety and fire concerns. (We received presoldered parts to work the labs on.)
The course was good overall
fine

It was a very good online course. I thought the labs were excellent for a remote setting and very enjoyable. The first three labs were extremely time consuming however. I would say the first lab took about 7 hours to figure out.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are interested in electrical circuits, then yes.
It seems to lay the foundations of the rest of the EE classes, so yes.
Yes, if you're interested in going a little bit more in depth into circuit analysis, it's a good class!  A lot of the things that were glossed over in EE 200 get explained here, which I appreciated.
Yeah, I liked some of the labs quite a bit.
Be prepared to put in consistent effort and show up for the labs! Very useful for any aspiring EE major.
yes. it is needed for the major and is a useful course
only if they need to take it

I would highly recommend this course after taking differential equations (specifically ENAS194). There is a lot of math involved in the class and it was extremely useful to have practice with Laplace Transforms and Fourier Series before having to apply them to circuits. Even if you are an EECS major, take differential equations!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In addition to live virtual lectures, there were also virtual lab sessions almost every week.

Professor Tang requested that all students attend live virtual lectures, but he would upload recordings of the lectures for later viewing as well. The class also had a virtual lab component, but I don't believe attendance was required.
We also had a 3 hour virtual lab usually once per week.
live virtual labs as well.

Plus hands on lab kit with mailed components. This semester, we each received a giant set of electronics, including the Analog Devices ADALM learning module and education kits. The set also contained a power supply, multimeter, radio, circuits .etc which I am really grateful for. This let us get hands on experience with the tools of the trade for any electrical engineer!
NA
lecture and lab both virtual
Live virtual lecture that was recorded along with a virtual lab session
